Making appropriations for the Departments of Labor, Health and Human Services, and Education, and related agencies, for the fiscal year ending September 30, 1994, and for other purposes.

action.text: Final Day of Subcommittee Mark-up.
Mr. Rogers reserved all points of order against the bill.
The House Committee on Appropriations reported an original measure, H. Rept. 103-156, by Mr. Natcher.
Committee Consideration and Mark-up Session Held.

calendar.text: Placed on the Union Calendar, Calendar No. 88.

action.text: Considered as privileged matter.
Mr. Natcher moved to resolve into the Committee of the Whole House on the state of the Union.

Pending the foregoing motion, Mr. Natcher asked unanimous consent that the time for general debate on the bill be limited to not to exceed one hour, equally divided between Mr. Natcher and Mr. Porter. Agreed to without objection.
On motion to resolve into Committee of the Whole House on the state of the Union Agreed to by voice vote.
The Speaker designated the Honorable Philip R. Sharp to act as Chairman of the Committee.
DEBATE - Pursuant to the previous unanimous consent agreement, the Committee of the Whole proceeded with one hour of general debate.

Mrs. Schroeder raised a point of order against the content of the measure. Ms. Schroeder stated that Sec. 207 of the bill constituted legislation on an appropriations bill The Chair sustained the point of order.
Mr. Natcher asked unanimous consent that debate on the bill and all amendments thereto conclude no later than 1 p.m. Agreed to without objection.

EXTENSION OF TIME FOR GENERAL DEBATE - Mr. Natcher asked unanimous consent that the time for general debate on the bill and, all amendments thereto, be extende for an additional 20 minutes, equally divided and controlled by Mr. Hyde and Ms. Schroeder. Agreed to without objection.
GENERAL DEBATE - Pursuant to the previous unanimous consent agreement, the Committee of the Whole proceeded with twenty minutes of general debate.
Mr. Natcher moved for the Committee of the Whole to rise and report.
On motion to rise and report Failed by recorded vote: 190 - 244 (Roll no. 306).
Mr. Natcher moved for the Committee of the Whole to rise and report.
On motion to rise and report Agreed to by voice vote.
The House rose from the Committee of the Whole House on the state of the Union to report H.R. 2518.
The previous question was ordered without objection.
The House adopted the remaining amendments en gross as agreed to by the Committee of the Whole House on the state of the Union.
Mr. Livingston moved to recommit with instructions to Appropriations.

DEBATE - The House proceeded with ten minutes of debate on the motion to recommit the bill to the Committee on Appropriations with instructions to report the bill back to the House with an amendment to reduce the appropriations for discretionary funding in the bill back to 1993 levels.
The previous question on the motion to recommit with instructions was ordered without objection.
On motion to recommit with instructions Failed by recorded vote: 158 - 267 (Roll no. 310).

vote.text: On passage Passed by the Yeas and Nays: 305 - 124 (Roll no. 311).

action.text: Motion to reconsider laid on the table Agreed to without objection.
Received in the Senate and read twice and referred to the Committee on Appropriations.
Subcommittee on Labor, HHS, and Education. Approved for full committee consideration with amendments favorably.

calendar.text: Committee on Appropriations. Ordered to be reported with amendments favorably.

action.text: Committee on Appropriations. Reported to Senate by Senator Harkin with amendments. With written report No. 103-143.

calendar.text: Placed on Senate Legislative Calendar under General Orders. Calendar No. 201.

action.text: Measure laid before Senate.

vote.text: Passed Senate with amendments by Yea-Nay Vote. 82-17. Record Vote No: 295.

action.text: Senate insists on its amendments asks for a conference, appoints conferees Harkin; Byrd; Hollings; Inouye; Bumpers; Reid; Kohl; Murray; Specter; Hatfield; Stevens; Cochran; Gorton; Mack; Bond.
Mr. Natcher asked unanimous consent that the House disagree to the Senate amendments, and agree to a conference.
On motion that the House disagree to the Senate amendments, and agree to a conference Agreed to without objection.
Motion to reconsider laid on the table Agreed to without objection.
Mr. Porter moved that the House instruct conferees.

DEBATE - The House proceeded with one hour of debate on the Porter motion to instruct conferees. The instructions contained in the motion require the managers on the part of the House to agree to Senate amendment No. 24, regarding compensation for the death or disability of an employee.
The previous question was ordered without objection.
On motion that the House instruct conferees Agreed to by voice vote.
Motion to reconsider laid on the table Agreed to without objection.
The Speaker appointed conferees: Natcher, Smith (IA), Obey, Stokes, Hoyer, Pelosi, Lowey, Serrano, DeLauro, Porter, Young (FL), Bentley, Bonilla, and McDade.
Motion to reconsider laid on the table Agreed to without objection.
Message on Senate action sent to the House.
Mr. Natcher asked unanimous consent that managers on the part of the House have until midnight on Oct. 5 to file a conference report on H.R. 2518. Agreed to without objection.
Conferees agreed to file conference report.
Conference report H. Rept. 103-275 filed with 36 amendments in disagreement. Filed late, pursuant to previous special order.
Mr. Natcher brought up conference report H. Rept. 103-275 by previously agreed to special order.
DEBATE - The House proceeded with one hour of debate.
The previous question was ordered without objection.

vote.text: On agreeing to the conference report Agreed to by the Yeas and Nays: 311 - 115 (Roll no. 486).

bill.summary: 10/7/1993--House receded and concurred with amendment. TABLE OF CONTENTS: Title I: Department of Labor Title II: Department of Health and Human Services Title III: Department of Education Title IV: Related Agencies Title V: General Provisions Departments of Labor, Health and Human Services, and Education, and Related Agencies Appropriations Act, 1994 - Title I: Department of Labor - Department of Labor Appropriations Act, 1994 - Makes appropriations for FY 1994 for agencies within the Department of Labor. (Sec. 102) Prohibits benefit payments from the Employees' Compensation Fund for individuals convicted of defrauding the compensation program. Title II: Department of Health and Human Services - Department of Health and Human Services Appropriations Act, 1994 - Makes appropriations for FY 1994 for agencies within the Department of Health and Human Services. Provides limitations on the use of appropriated funds. Title III: Department of Education - Department of Education Appropriations Act, 1994 - Makes appropriations for FY 1994 for agencies and programs within the Department of Education. Sets forth general provisions relating to the use of appropriated funds. (Sec. 304) Prohibits the use of funds to prevent the implementation of programs of voluntary prayer and meditation in the public schools. Title IV: Related Agencies - Makes appropriations for FY 1994 for the following agencies or programs: (1) ACTION; (2) Corporation for Public Broadcasting; (3) Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service; (4) Federal Mine Safety and Health Review Commission; (5) National Commission on Libraries and Information Science; (6) National Council on Disability; (7) National Labor Relations Board; (8) National Mediation Board; (9) Occupational Safety and Health Review Commission; (10) Physician Payment Review Commission; (11) Prospective Payment Assessment Commission; (12) Railroad Retirement Board; (13) Soldiers' and Airmen's Home; (14) United States Institute of Peace; and (15) United States Naval Home. Title V: General Provisions - Sets forth provisions on the use of the appropriated funds. (Sec. 506) Prohibits the use of funds to carry out any program of distributing sterile needles for the hypodermic injection of any illegal drug unless the Surgeon General determines that such programs are effective in preventing the spread of HIV and do not encourage the use of illegal drugs. Authorizes the use of such funds for demonstration or study purposes. (Sec. 507) Requires expenditures under this Act to comply with the Buy American Act. (Sec. 508) Provides for the calculation of black lung monthly benefit payments for months after December 1993 and before October 1994. Rescinds certain amounts made available to the community investment program under a dire emergency supplemental appropriation. (Sec. 510) Prohibits the expenditure of funds for any abortion except when it is made known to the appropriate Federal entity or official that such procedure is necessary to save the life of the mother or that the pregnancy is the result of an act of rape or incest.
